journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Rate regulation of a suborbital reentry payload by moving-mass actuators

author-notes.corresp: Aidin Mohammadi, Aerospace Research Institute, PO Box 14665-834, Tehran, Iran. Email: mohammadi@ari.ac.ir

abstract.p: In order to save cost and time, sounding rockets are effectively used to develop space technologies. In a biological payload that is under the study on this investigation, reentry rate regulation is one of the critical issues to be solved. Because of non-linear time-varying dynamics of these payloads and presence of high aerodynamic disturbances during reentry, choosing an appropriate stability and control mechanism can be an engineering challenge. Having a lot of benefits, nowadays, moving-mass actuation systems are used in a variety of aerospace applications. As an innovative approach, a moving-mass system is designed and analysed to regulate the payload body rates during reentry phase. Simulation results indicate significant performance of suggested application for moving-mass control systems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cone-cylinder and flat-faced circular cylinder suborbital payloads, during reentry, fall into tumbling, coning, and flat spin angular motions. Experiments and flight tests show that payloads tumble several times just after they enter high-density atmosphere. Then, they transfer into a final flat spin through an intermediate coning motion.1,2 These facts increase the emphasis on the need for angular rate control of suborbital payloads to ensure that vehicle and instruments it carries will survive during the reentry phase. Biological suborbital payloads, which are under the study in this article, put new limitations on allowable angular rate which require an angular rate control system. The controller can de-tumble payload and prevent it from ingoing coning and flat-spin during reentry.

A schematic trajectory of a suborbital sounding rocket including flight phases and events are shown in Figure 1. Different patterns may be utilized to reduce the velocity of a sounding rocket payload during reentry phase to guarantee a safe parachute deployment, such as using supersonic brake parachutes, using aerodynamic brake plates, increasing drag by rising angle of attack to 90°, or reentry in zero angle of attack after nose ejection. According to biological uses of the reentry capsule and positioning of animal in the capsule, it is necessary to recover the payload vertically with a high drag flight which can be provided by nose ejection. Therefore, the third method is considered in this article. Figure 1.
A schematic flight trajectory of sounding rockets.

Choosing the control mechanism is the key point of de-tumbling problem. There are many different control mechanisms being developed with the ability of attitude rate control, but all concepts essentially fall into three categories: aerodynamic load, jet thrust, and inertial load mechanisms.3 In applications such as the control of reentry vehicles at extreme Mach numbers, the aerodynamic heating and drag penalties make it impractical to deploy flight control surfaces. Similarly, high aerodynamic moments, which cause angular motions, prevent jet trust mechanisms to be applicable in this case. But, of the various methods that may be used to control the angular rate of a reentry vehicle, moving-mass control system (MMCS), which is a good example of inertial control mechanisms, appears to offer the greatest design and cost advantages.

The basic principle by which MMCS is able to regulate the angular rate of a reentry vehicle is quite simple. An internal mass element is laterally moved within the payload body and changes the vehicle centre of mass. This change of CM generates the desired control moments through the external aerodynamic moments. The design of reentry control systems using moving-mass actuation appears to be suitable and conceptually straightforward. As far as extreme aerodynamic forces are available during reentry, greater control moments can be generated by adjusting the centre of mass. The gravitational force plays no role whatsoever in the operation of an MMCS, because it acts at the centre of mass, and has no moment on the system.4

Previous research has demonstrated the ability of moving-mass actuation system in a variety of aerospace control and stability applications. Despite the apparent advantages of these actuation systems, comprehensive literature reviews have uncovered surprisingly little information on the design, implementation, and performance of these actuators on reentry rate regulation.

The application of a moving-mass roll control system to control the roll attitude and trajectory of a maneuvering reentry lifting body is investigated in Petsopoulos et al.4. Application of MMCS on integrated guidance and control of kinetic warheads is discussed5–11. A nine-degree-of-freedom (DOF) simulation motion of a kinetic warhead with three moving-masses actuators is developed.5 A game-theoretic approach to the design of robust integrated guidance control system for a moving-mass-actuated kinetic warhead is presented.6 Implementation of different control methods in these moving-mass-actuated warheads are also presented.7–11 A vibrating inertial mass control mechanism applicable to both fin and spin-stabilized projectiles is investigated in literature.12,13 The research presented in Mukherjee and Balaram14 and Balaram15 is motivated by application of ring shape path moving masses for reentry aero maneuver vehicle. A non-linear 8-DOF simulation of spinning vehicle with two internal moving elements demonstrates the ability of hybrid attitude control scheme on the mass position.16,17

Given the apparent lack of information on MMCS applications for reentry angular rate regulations, the objective of this research is to establish the feasibility of designing moving-mass-actuated reentry rate-control systems for a flat-faced circular cylinder suborbital sounding rocket payload. This feasibility demonstration is achieved through a non-linear 6-DOF simulation of rigid body motion coupled with dynamic of additional moving masses. The governing equations of motion and detailed modeling of coupled reentry payload and moving-masses system are the main subjects of study. Based on this foundation, a non-linear 8-DOF simulation is developed for payload in conjunction with two moving masses constrained to cross-shape lateral translation path. While the purpose of this article is to discuss the concept and ability of MMCS on such missions, but not excellence of control method, a simple PI feedback control is used to regulate body rates fed by rate gyros.

sec.title: Mathematical model and simulation architecture
sec.p:
Governing general form of payload’s equations of motion coupled with moving-masses dynamics, aerodynamic forces and moments, and environmental models are subjects of this section. Structure of non-linear simulation of these models is illustrated by a simple block diagram (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Block diagram of non-linear MMCS simulation.

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p: This part will present the formulation of dynamic model for a payload consisting of n internal moving masses, which is allowed to translate within the vehicle body cavity, but not allowed to rotate with respect to it. Both the payload body and the moving masses are assumed to be rigid bodies, and no simplifying assumptions are made. The equations of motion of MMCS-actuated payload are derived using Kane’s method, which is an efficient method for accommodating constrained motions.18 The translational dynamic equations for the payload body centre of mass (dependent from system centre of mass) are derived through force balancing. They are given by5 (1)mT→·VB+mTg(ω→B×V→Bg)-F→B-g→B=∑i=1nmig(r→i×→·ωB-→··ri-ω→B×g(ω→B×r→i+2→·rig)g) the rotation kinetic differential equations are obtained by similar approach (2)IB→·ωB+ω→B×IBω→B-M→B=∑i=1nmig[r→i×→·VB+r→i×→··rig.-g.r→i×ω→B×g(V→B+ω→B×r→i+2→·rig)gg-r→i×g(r→i×→·ωBg)+r→i×g→Bg] the dynamic equations of motion for all internal translating masses are collectively given by equation (3) (3)∀i=1:ngarrowmib→iTg(→·VB-r→i×→·ωB+ω→Bg g×g(V→B+ω→B×r→i+2→·rig)-g→Bg)+miδ··i=ui

A closer examination of equations (1) and (2) reveals that the left hand sides of these equations have the same form as the Newton and Euler rigid-body force equations, which are resolved in a centre of mass body-fixed frame, and all additional terms appearing on the right hand sides present effects of the relative motion of the moving mass and the payload body. These additional terms can be taken as forces and moments affecting a rigid body, and then dynamical equations of this rigid body have to be augmented with kinematical equations for final simulation development.19 In other words, when the actuator masses are moved, they must be accelerated and then decelerated, and during these transients, payload experiences time-varying forces and moments that affect its orientation with respect to disturbances and might even affect disturbances themselves. Since controller design procedure is based on the plant multi-body dynamics including all the mentioned effects, the control law affords to damp disturbances.

Cross-product of mass positions and payload velocity in the first term of equation (2) on the right hand side is the manifestation of control moments produced by MMCS displacements. Other additional terms present the dynamic coupling that exist between moving masses and payload. For instance, mir→i×g(r→i×→·ωBg) in equation (2) represents the effects of ith moving mass on the change of moment of inertia of the system. These equations clearly indicate that MMCS must control a system that is characterized by highly non-linear cross-coupling. However, non-linear simulation of our 8-DOF case study, which is presented in next section, reveals that MMCS is quite capable of regulating angular rates.

sec.title: Aerodynamic model
sec.p: During exoatmospheric flight, the only force acting on system is gravity which plays no role in the operation of MMCS. So, while there is no other external force before entering atmosphere, MMCS is completely impractical for rate regulation. But, after entering the atmosphere in addition to the acceleration caused by gravity, the payload will experience aerodynamic force that is the dominant external force and can be used for payload de-tumbling. These forces are computed using the expressions19 (4)F→B=12ρV2Srefg[-CA-Lref2VqCAqCY+Lref2Vg(rCYr+pCYpg)-CN-Lref2VqCNqg] where the aerodynamic force coefficients (CA, CAq, CY, CYr, CYp, CN, CNq) are specified as functions of Mach number, the angle of attack, α, and side slip, β, and are interpolated from tabular data computed using aerodynamic software. Aerodynamic moments are available by a similar model19 (5)M→B=12ρV2SrefLrefg[Cl+Lref2Vg(rClr+pClpg)Cm+Lref2VqCmq+CZLrefg(xcgR-xcgg)Cn+Lref2Vg(rClr+pClpg)-CYLrefg(xcgR-xcgg)g]

For simplicity of calculations, all coefficients are obtained with respect to a fixed reference point located at the nose of payload. So, a moment arm (xcgR − xcg) appears in the model which couples CZ into Cm and CY into Cn.

sec.title: Environmental models
sec.p: In this part, characteristics of environmental models that are commonly used in the flight simulation of space access vehicles will be described. These models include atmosphere and gravity.

Aerodynamic forces depend on certain properties of the atmosphere among other factors. The basic atmospheric property needed to calculate aerodynamic force in incompressible flow is the density (ρ). To calculate aerodynamic forces under conditions of compressible flow, sound speed (a) in ambient air is also required. Atmospheric data are usually supplied to a flight simulation in the form of tabulated data as functions of altitude. Since meteorological conditions constantly vary, there is no ‘normal’ atmosphere. However, a representative set of conditions, called a standard atmosphere, has been defined for use in analyses.20 In addition to the standard atmosphere, certain variations in atmospheric conditions have been adopted to define a standard hot day, a standard cold day, and so forth. In this simulation, we have used the 1976 COESA-extended US standard atmosphere data.

Many different models exist for gravity: flat earth, spherical earth, and elliptical earth. Elliptical earth model is the most complete model. In this simulation, we have used the elliptical earth model for estimating the value of g with the effect of altitude and latitude (WGS-84).19

sec.title: Simulation architecture
sec.p: The ability of the moving-mass-actuated system to control the highly coupled non-linear dynamic of payload during re-entry must be demonstrated using a non-linear simulation of equations of motion. A re-entry payload trajectory is formed by forces and torques due to earth’s gravity and aerodynamic effects. Also, the motion of the payload is highly affected by centre of mass position that changes by moving masses. These changes are conducted via servo actuators according to control law which provides target requirements. In practice, implementation of a closed-loop control system needs to know the system states that are provided by measurement unit. A simplified block diagram of the non-linear flight simulation is provided in Figure 2.

sec.title: MMCS design and modeling
sec.p: This section will present payload and masses configuration in our case study. Design parameters, actuation model, and control system are discussed here.

sec.title: Payload and moving-mass system design
sec.p:
A sketch of the payload configuration is shown in Figure 3. The payload consists of a flat-faced cylinder rigid body with two (n = 2) moving masses that can move in two cross-shape cavities, parallel to the lateral orthogonal axes of the vehicle (y, z). Actuators inside the payload body exert internal forces on the masses to move them inside the cavity to a desired location. Based on this concept, unit vectors of moving-mass cavities are given as follows (6)by=g(010g),bz=g(001g) Position and velocity vectors of the actuator masses with respect to the body frame are given as follows (7)r→y=g(-xoffsetδy0g),r→z=g(-xoffset0δzg), →·ry=g(0δ·y0g),→·rz=g(00δ·zg) Figure 3.
Moving mass payload concept (side and rear views).

In this study, payload length and diameter are, respectively, 1.8 and 0.6 m. Payload centre of mass is located at 75 cm from payload face and moving-mass cavities are assumed to be 40 cm behind payload centre of mass. So, in equation (7), xoffset is 0.4 m. Because of payload diameter limitation, allowable length for cavities is around 50 cm and mass displacements (δz, δy) can be in the range ±0.25 m. The values of the mass properties of system obtained from mission conceptual design are given as follows (8)IB=g(14.64000111.6000111.6g),mP=300kgmy=mz=2.0kgmT=mP+my+mz

sec.title: Servo actuator model
sec.p: To examine the performance of payload rate regulation with this control mechanism, an actuator must be used to move the internal mass in a prescribed manner. The actuator force exerted on the internal moving masses is modeled by a feedback linearization controller. The controller gains are chosen to yield an un-damped natural frequency of 28 Hz, with 0.71 damping ratio. So, for commanded displacement as δic, the force is presented by (9)ui=-kPg(δi-δicg)-kDδ·i Corresponding to desired natural frequency and damping ratio and 2.0 kg masses, the proportional gain kP and the derivative gain kD can be chosen as 1600 and 160, respectively.

sec.title: Rate regulation control and stability
sec.p:
Since in this article control law is intended to be a simple method of providing rate regulation in each pitch and yaw channel, a fairly simple PI control was chosen for this study. Therefore, a non-linear model of plant is simplified and decoupled for planar motion in pitch channel, and then a PI controller is designed via linearization of planar model and pole placement method. For developing a planar model, assume that the horizontal component of velocity is negligible in the reentry phase; by this assumption, it is possible to take pitch angle θ as angle of attack α (Figure 4). Also, for planar model, pitch rate θ· can be taken equivalent with y-axis body rate q. Figure 4.
Planar model concept.

Expanding equations (2) and (7) for planar motion and assuming my to be fixed at the centre, the non-linear model is reduced as follows (10)mzδzV·cosθ+mzxoffsetV·sinθ+Iyθ··+mzδz2θ··+mzxoffset2θ··+mzxoffsetδ··z+2mzδzδ·zθ·-mzδzgcosθ-mzxoffsetgsinθ=12ρV2SrefLrefg(Cm+Lref2Vθ·Cmq+CZLrefg(xcgR-xcgg)g) and acceleration is given by (11)V·=g-mzρV2Sref2mTg(CAcosθ+CNsinθg) so equation (10) can be written as follows (12)mzρV2Sref2mTg(-δzCAcos2θ-δzCNcosθsinθgg-xoffsetCAcosθsinθ-xoffsetCNsin2θg)+mzxoffsetδ··z+2mzδzδ·zθ·+g(Iy+mzg(δz2+xoffset2g)g)θ··=12ρV2SrefLrefg(Cm+Lref2Vθ·Cmq+CZLrefg(xcgR-xcgg)g) Linearization of payload’s pitch moment equation (equation (12)) resulted in the following second-order differential equation (13)θ··=Cθ·θ·+Cθθ+Cδδz where its coefficients are given by (14)Cθ·=ρVSrefLref2Cmq4g(Iy+mzxoffset2g)Cθ=ρV2SrefLrefg(Cmα+CNαLrefg(xcgR-xcgg)g)2g(Iy+mzxoffset2g)Cδ=mzρV2SrefCA2mTg(Iy+mzxoffset2g) where Cmα and CNα are the aerodynamic derivatives of pitch moment and normal force with respect to angle of attack. This linear plant may also be expressed in standard state-space format as follows (15)X·=g[01CθCθ·g]X+g[0Cδg]U where (16)X=g[θθ·g],U=δz

These linear coefficients are illustrated in Figure 5 for a nominal trajectory of a payload dropped from 150 km height. It can be seen that in the exoatmospheric flight, all coefficients are near zero and this means that the plant does not have inner dynamic and it is not controllable by MMCS. During reentry, payload experiences extremely critical condition in maximum dynamic pressure and after that enters steady descend regime. By this point of view, dynamic pressure condition is chosen for designing control law. During this phase, the linear model can be as follows (17)X·=g[01-84.20.6g]X+g[0-1.4g]U Simple PI feedback law, used for pitch rate regulation, is given by (18)δz=kpθ·-ki∫τ=0tθ·dτ=kpθ·-kiθ Figure 5.
Linear coefficients of nominal trajectory versus time.

A linear control system design procedure, involving pole placement method, yielded the gains 5.0 and 1.0, respectively, for kp and ki. Exerting (18) into (17) simplifies the controlled plant as follows (19)X·=g[01-82.8-6.3g]X=A~X

It is clear that uncontrolled model of payload (equation (17)) has positive eigenvalues, which means that the system is unstable. Having controlled linear model (equation (19)) makes it possible to analyse the stability of designed control law. For a linear Lyapunov stability analysis, after choosing a positive indefinite matrix Q, Lyapunov equation must be solved for P matrix (20)A~P+PA~T+Q=0

For the stability of the system, it is required that matrix P be positive indefinite. In this case, choosing identity matrix causes P and its leading principal minors to be written as follows (21)P=g[0.11-0.5-0.56.64g],p11=0.11 ,g|p11p12p21p22g|=0.53 so matrix P is positive indefinite, which means that designed rate regulator is stable for maximum dynamic pressure. Controlled model of payload during steady descend regime can be written as follows (22)X·=g[01-11.0-0.4g]X Performing Lyapunov analysis for this regime yields (23)P=g[1.38-0.5-0.515.0g],p11=1.38,g|p11p12p21p22g|=20.47

This positive matrix P ensures that controller remains stable up until end of flight. All these analyses reveal the ability of designed rate regulation system in a simple planar model. In the next section, a numerical simulation of full non-linear coupled equation of motion is used to examine the ability of designed controller.

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p:
Based on presented mathematical models, simulation structure in Figure 2, payload, and MMCS configuration, a non-linear simulation of the full 8-DOF coupled equations of motion was developed and used to study the performance of proposed mechanism. Simulation results are available for a payload dropped vertically from 150 km height and zero velocity. Height, velocity, and Mach number of trajectory are illustrated in Figures 6 to 8. Figure 6.
Payload altitude versus time.
Figure 7.
Payload velocity versus time. Figure 8.
Payload Mach number versus time.

The results of the numerical simulation of the payload and MMCS are presented for both forms, controlled and uncontrolled simulations. Uncontrolled behavior was obtained by running a 6-DOF payload simulation, assuming that moving masses were fixed at the centre of cavities.

The payload’s pitch and yaw rates are plotted versus time in Figures 9 and 10. Uncontrolled plots show that oscillations start after entering atmosphere at 80 km, because of some aerodynamic asymmetry characteristic of payload. Tumbling and oscillations grow up by passing through a dense atmosphere of 30 km height up to 1000°/s. In Figure 9, a constant rate can be seen after some oscillations which demonstrate entering in coning motion and flat spin after initial tumbling. As can be seen from plots, controlled behavior validates the ability of MMCS for reentry rate regulation. More details of controlled behavior are illustrated in Figures 11 and 12. Figure 9.
Payload pitch rate versus time (uncontrolled in detail).
Figure 10.
Payload yaw rate versus time (uncontrolled in detail).
Figure 11.
Payload pitch rate versus time (controlled in detail).
Figure 12.
Payload yaw rate versus time (controlled in detail).

Comparison of controlled and uncontrolled rates show that, at the beginning of tumbling, both trajectories have similar behaviors, but MMCS prevents rate oscillations from growing up and body rates stay within 1°/s during reentry. The relative positions of moving masses with respect to payload’s body are illustrated in Figures 13 and 14. The smooth motion of the moving masses at the beginning of plot belongs to exoatmospheric phase where MMCS has no control authority. After entering atmosphere, masses start to oscillate and act as active rate dampers. An interesting aspect of this result is that masses did not return to the zero displacement at the centre of cavity after rate regulation. This is because aerodynamic asymmetry and masses try to regulate its effects; so they must stay at non-zero positions. Resulted centre of mass trajectory in the rear view of payload section can be seen in Figure 15. Tendency to one side of zero position is obvious in this figure. Figure 13.
Lateral-actuated mass position versus time.
Figure 14.
Longitudinal-actuated mass position versus time.
Figure 15.
Centre of mass trajectory of payload and moving masses.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This investigation is conducted to determine the ability of a MMCS for body rate regulation and de-tumbling of suborbital reentry payload. This article described the concept, modeling, and simulation of a MMCS for reentry phase of a flat-faced sounding rocket payload. Great forces effecting payload during reentry prepare sufficient control moments and make internal mass actuation mechanism an appropriate methodology for rate regulation problem. Because this was a preliminary study on a new application of moving mass, great emphasis was put on modeling, simulation, and validation of its ability, but excellence of control law remains for future studies.

Despite the limitations of this preliminary investigation, MMCS appears to be a relatively simple and effective method of regulating body rates of reentry payloads and it deserves serious attention as a viable control mechanism on a suborbital reentry payloads. The results presented here demonstrate that the MMCS can produce significant control authority for payload de-tumbling, thus preventing it from falling into coning motion and flat spin.

Future research will examine the effect of non-linear control theories on the performance of system and will study the behavior of other mass configurations like ring-shape cavities. Hardware used in loop tests and investigation on the practical aspect of mass-actuated systems will also be of future interest.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors wish to acknowledge the Aerospace Research Institute for their financial support on this investigation.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors thank the valuable remarks and suggestions made by reviewers which led to many improvements in the paper.

mass of ith translational moving mass
